A small rural school in Michigan is going green, thanks to the fact that it's one of the windiest places in the country.
The primary school and the school superintendent's house are now getting their power from wind.
And that's just the beginning.
From member station WCMU, Amy Robinson reports.
The Laker School sits on a blacktop two-lane road out in the middle of what's called Michigan's rural thumb.
The school is surrounded by wind turbines.
Dozens of utility-scale turbines turn in the breeze.
You might think even Don Quixote would appreciate these gentle giants if only he had attended Laker schools.
The district is embracing renewable energy in a big way.
We've received biodiesel grants.
We have received energy smart incentives.
We've received recently a biomass grant.
Kathy Dickens is the junior high principal and by all accounts a skilled grant writer.
Three years ago, she got her first grant, more than a quarter million dollars, from the Michigan Public Service Commission.
She purchased three large refurbished wind turbines to power the elementary school.
I knew that utility-scale wind developers at that time were knocking on the doors of farmers.
